_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


1	The HWRT Terminal ¿ Norris City, LLC (HWRT) facility is a terminal for the storage and distribution of various fuels.  Petroleum products (i.e., gasoline and diesel) are received by pipeline.  Transport trucks deliver ethanol and other additives to the facility.  Transport trucks deliver the products to the facility¿s customers.  HWRT has decided to activate a 30,000 gallon butane storage tank and add a butane injection process to the facility.  Butane has been identified by the Environmental Protection Agency as a regulated substance subject to section 112 (r) of the Clean Air Act, which required the preparation of this Risk Management Plan (RMP).  HWRT is also subject to the OSHA process safety management standard and is submitting a program level 3 Risk Management Plan.

The initial construction of the terminal facility was completed in 1960, and it included construction of Tanks NC-01 through NC-04.  Tank NC-05 was constructed in 1987.  HWRT Terminal ¿ Norris City, LLC purchased the terminal from Crown Central Petroleum Corporation in 2004.

The facility is located on Cherry Street, approximately 0.5 mile west of U.S. Highway 1 and 0.25 mile north of Main Street in Norris City.  The immediate vicinity is sparsely populated; however, the closest residence is across the street from the facility¿s exit gate.  The facility has eleven fuel and additive storage tanks having capacities from 1000 to 2,538,753 gallons.  Each of these tanks is provided with adequate secondary containment.  

2	It is HWRT¿s policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local rules and regulations.

The owners and management of this facility regard employee and public safety as a very serious matter and have taken many precautions to maintain a safe working and public environment.  Some of these precautions include:

* Generating a Facility Response Plan (FRP);
* Generating a Spill, Prevention, Control and Countermeasure (SPCC) Plan;
* Instituti

ng safe operating procedures;
* Training employees in safety programs and procedures; and
* Coordinating with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

The FRP includes information regarding emergency response, hazard identification, various discharge scenarios, descriptions of periodic drills and exercises and describes employee training.  The SPCC Plan includes similar information as well as facility inspection forms.  Employees are typically provided with emergency response training, on-the-job training , spill prevention and spill response training and other supplemental training.


3	Process Description

The planned butane injection process is fairly simple.  Liquified butane gas will be delivered in tank trucks and pumped into the butane tank.  Butane is stored under ambient temperatures which can exceed 100 degrees F in the summer.  Butane will be injected into gasoline by pumping it into the pipeline as the gasoline is being delivered to HWRT.  

4	Worst-case release scenario.

The Clean Air Act risk management planning regulations require HWRT to prepare a worst-case scenario consisting of the release of the entire contents of the largest vessel containing a regulated chemical.  The largest butane-containing vessel is a 30,000 gallon tank, whose contents could be as much as 144,300 pounds.  The worst-case release is assumed to result in a vapor cloud containing the total quantity of butane in a concentration that is assumed to be between the upper and lower flammability limits of butane.  For the worst-case consequence analysis, the vapor cloud is assumed to detonate.

The endpoint for the consequence analysis of a vapor cloud explosion is an overpressure of one pound per square inch (1 psi).  The ¿Automated Resource for Chemical Hazard Incident Evaluation¿ (ARCHIE) software was used to estimate the distance to this endpoint.  

The worst-case scenario assumptions are as follows:

* The entire contents of the tank are released.
* T

he gas is liquefied by pressure, not refrigerated.
* The explosion occurs near ground level.
* There is no passive mitigation.

The estimated ¿distance to endpoint¿ is 1457 (0.28 miles) feet using ARCHIE software.  The public receptors within this distance include at least one residence and an industrial area.  Schools, hospitals, prisons, recreation areas, major commercial or office areas, national/state parks/monuments and wildlife refuges are not present inside this radius.  The population within this area was estimated at 18 using the ¿Landview 6¿ software program by selecting the ¿calculate population using block points¿ option.  The Landview software contains the latest (2000) census data available.  

5	Alternative Release scenario
HWRT is required to identify and analyze at least one alternative release scenario that is more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario.  The scenario selected involves a leak while transferring butane from a truck to the tank due to a gasket failure or hose failure.  This is a potential failure mode identified during the Process Hazard Analysis.  The pressure drop in the hose would be detected by a sensor and the truck¿s automatic excess flow shut-off valve would be activated and the butane flow would be stopped.  The contents of the hose could be released.

The hose is a nominal 3 inch diameter and the length is an estimated 30 to 50 feet long.  A 50 foot length will be utilized for a conservative scenario.  The volume of the hose is approximately 2.5 cubic feet.  Using a conversion factor of 7.48052 gallons per cubic feet and a butane density of 4.81 lb per gallon, the hose could hold about 90 pounds of butane.  For an extremely conservative scenario, it will be assumed that twice the total volume of the hose leaks out before the shut-off mechanism is activated so the total release would be 180 pounds.

This release is also assumed to result in a vapor cloud of butane in a concentration that is assumed to

be between the upper and lower flammability limits of butane that will detonate.

The endpoint for the consequence analysis of a vapor cloud explosion is an overpressure of one pound per square inch (1 psi).  The ¿Automated Resource for Chemical Hazard Incident Evaluation¿ (ARCHIE) software was used to estimate the distance to this endpoint.  

The alternative release scenario assumptions are as follows:

* 180 pounds of butane are released.
* The gas is liquefied by pressure, not refrigerated.
* The explosion occurs near ground level.
* There is no passive mitigation.

The estimated ¿distance to endpoint¿ is 157 feet (0.03 miles) using ARCHIE software.  No public receptors are within this distance.  Schools, residences, hospitals, prisons, recreation areas, and major commercial, industrial or office areas, national/state parks/monuments and wildlife refuges are not present inside this radius.  
The population within this area was estimated as 0 using the ¿Landview 6¿ software program by selecting the ¿calculate population using block points¿ option.  The Landview software contains the latest (2000) census data available.  

5	General accidental release prevention program

This facility has a strong commitment to the safe handling of butane and other flammable materials and to minimizing the probability of an accidental release.  This is achieved through a combination of safety equipment, personnel training and operating procedures.  The safety equipment includes excess flow valves, pressure relief valves and emergency shut off valves.  The butane tank and supporting equipment was inspected, tested and refurbished in October, 2005 prior to initiating the butane process at this facility.

6	Five-year accident history

This facility has not had a release of butane or any regulated substance as defined in 40 CFR 68.3 and 68.130 (or an OSHA highly hazardous chemical as defined in 40 CFR 29.1910(b)).

7	Emergency response program

The facility ha

s a comprehensive emergency response program, a Facility Response Plan and a Spill, Prevention, Control and Countermeasure (SPCC) Plan.  The Facility Response Plan contains specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of butane, procedures to inform the public and health care information.  All employees working with butane are trained in handling flammable materials and are provided with annual refresher training.  This plan has been coordinated with the White County LEPC.  The telephone number for the LEPC is 618-375-7413.

8	Planned changes to improve safety

The planned changes (both procedural and equipment changes) were documented during and after the Process Hazard Analyses which were conducted on August 3, 2005.  These changes are listed below.  

*	Add % capacity gauge to butane tank.
*	Replace butane tank pressure gauge.
*	Inspect butane tank and piping prior to use.  Replace equipment as necessary.
*	Test and replace as necessary the pressure relief gauges on the butane tank.
*	Create a procedure for butane truck unloading.
*	Create a procedure for butane injection.

These changes were all completed on or before October 6, 2005.
